Award.AwardTitle: Tailoring Surface Properties of Ordered Mesoporous Materials by Incorporation of Organic Functionalities into Siliceous and Hybrid Frameworks
Award.AbstractNarration: The Analytical and Surface Chemistry (ASC) program of the Division of Chemistry will support the research program of Prof. Mietek Jaroniec of Kent State University. Prof. Jaroniec and his students will investigate ways to tailor the surface properties of periodic mesoporous organosilicas (PMOs) by employing a novel strategy, which involves the self assembly of reactive organosilicas and block copolymers accompanied by chemical reactions that lead to the formation of desired bridging and pendant organic groups. The study will result in new mesoporous materials with tailored surface and framework properties. The study will provide excellent training opportunities to graduate students who will be involved in this largely interdisciplinary project in the area of nanoscience and nanotechnology. Prof. Jaroniec and his students will also prepare and deliver a series of lectures to promote nanoscience and nanotechnology to students in area high schools.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Normal 0 false false false EN-US X-NONE X-NONE Nowadays there is a great need for the development of materials with desired surface area, porosity and surface properties for specific applications ranging from sorbents for the removal of pollutants from air and water and photocatalysts for degradation of toxic organic compounds to specially designed materials for supercapacitors, batteries and fuel cells. Earlier studies have shown that the well-defined porous materials can be synthesized by self-assembly of appropriate inorganic and organic precursors and block copolymers in acidic aqueous solutions. This one-pot synthesis involves selective accumulation of hydrophilic precursors in the hydrophilic domains of an ordered block copolymer used as a sacrificial structure directing agent (soft template). The aforementioned strategy has been successfully used for the development of various materials with ordered/uniform mesopores (pores having sizes between 2 and 50 nm). The research activities under this grant were focused on tailoring surface functionality of ordered mesoporous materials (OMM). Our research demonstrated that the commercially available organic compounds of silicon, known as organosilanes, can be used in the aforementioned one-pot synthesis of porous materials to introduce organic functionality into OMM, and consequently to alter their surface properties for specific applications. By preforming the organosilane-assisted self-assembly synthesis in the presence of a block copolymer template we were able to: (1) introduce specific organic functionalities into various OMM such as silica, alumina, carbons, and polymers, and (2) to use reactive precursors in the one-pot synthesis to form in-situ desired organic functionalities. The specific composite OMM with desired surface area, porosity and organic functionalities can be prepared by this strategy for various environmental and energy-related applications. The important aspects of this research are: (i) enrichment of our knowledge of the performance of chemical reactions in the specific domains of ordered block copolymer phases, (ii) extension of the concept of block copolymer-templating synthesis into reactive precursors, and (iii) development of novel composite OMM for various environmental and energy applications. The outcomes of this research include: (a) 22 articles published in internationally recognized scientific journals, (b) graduation of six doctoral students, one master-level student and one undergraduate honors student, (c) five undergraduate research projects, (d) a series of lectures for graduate and advanced undergraduate students through the course "Advanced Nanomaterials", (e) several presentations at national and international meetings, and (f) hosting ten international visiting researchers and five international graduate students from Brazil, China, Columbia, Ivory Coast, Korea, Poland, Spain and Ukraine. About 50% of the visiting researchers, as well as graduate and undergraduate students, were from underrepresented groups. Last Modified: 10/29/2013 Submitted by: Mietek Jaroniec
